trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create DNS zones for Azure DNS .This is a Step by step to get your first DNS zone created to start hosting your DNS domain.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create DNS zones for Azure DNS .This is a Step by step to get your first DNS zone created to start hosting your DNS domain.

trans-unit.source:
The domain ‘contoso.com’ may contain a number of DNS records, such as ‘mail.contoso.com’ (for a mail server) and ‘www.contoso.com’ (for a web site). A DNS zone is used to host the DNS records for a particular domain.

To start hosting your domain we need to first create a DNS zone. Any DNS record created for a particular domain will be inside a DNS zone for the domain.

These instructions use Microsoft Azure PowerShell. Be sure to update to the latest Azure PowerShell to use the Azure DNS cmdlets. The same steps can also be executed using the Microsoft Azure Command Line Interface, REST API or SDK.
trans-unit.target:
The domain ‘contoso.com’ may contain a number of DNS records, such as ‘mail.contoso.com’ (for a mail server) and ‘www.contoso.com’ (for a web site). A DNS zone is used to host the DNS records for a particular domain.

To start hosting your domain we need to first create a DNS zone. Any DNS record created for a particular domain will be inside a DNS zone for the domain.

These instructions use Microsoft Azure PowerShell. Be sure to update to the latest Azure PowerShell to use the Azure DNS cmdlets. The same steps can also be executed using the Microsoft Azure Command Line Interface, REST API or SDK.

trans-unit.source: The following steps need to be completed before you can manage Azure DNS using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The following steps need to be completed before you can manage Azure DNS using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS uses Azure Resource Manager (ARM). Make sure you switch PowerShell mode to use the ARM cmdlets. More info is available at Using Windows Powershell with Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS uses Azure Resource Manager (ARM). Make sure you switch PowerShell mode to use the ARM cmdlets. More info is available at Using Windows Powershell with Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Log in to your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to Authenticate with your credentials.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to Authenticate with your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.
trans-unit.target: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the ‘Get-AzureSubscription’ cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the ‘Get-AzureSubscription’ cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Create a new resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)
trans-unit.target: Create a new resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location. This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group. However, since all DNS resources are global, not regional, the choice of resource group location has no impact on Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location. This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group. However, since all DNS resources are global, not regional, the choice of resource group location has no impact on Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: The Azure DNS service is managed by the Microsoft.Network resource provider.
trans-unit.target: The Azure DNS service is managed by the Microsoft.Network resource provider.

trans-unit.source: Your Azure subscription needs to be registered to use this resource provider before you can use Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure subscription needs to be registered to use this resource provider before you can use Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: This is a one time operation for each subscription.
trans-unit.target: This is a one time operation for each subscription.

trans-unit.source:
Suppose two people or two processes try to modify a DNS record at the same time. Which one wins? And does the winner know that they’ve just overwritten changes created by someone else?

Azure DNS uses Etags to handle concurrent changes to the same resource safely. Each DNS resource (zone or record set) has an Etag associated with it. Whenever a resource is retrieved, its Etag is also retrieved. When updating a resource, you have the option to pass back the Etag so Azure DNS can verify that the Etag on the server matches. Since each update to a resource results in the Etag being re-generated, an Etag mismatch indicates a concurrent change has occurred. Etags are also used when creating a new resource to ensure that the resource does not already exist.
trans-unit.target:
Suppose two people or two processes try to modify a DNS record at the same time. Which one wins? And does the winner know that they’ve just overwritten changes created by someone else?

Azure DNS uses Etags to handle concurrent changes to the same resource safely. Each DNS resource (zone or record set) has an Etag associated with it. Whenever a resource is retrieved, its Etag is also retrieved. When updating a resource, you have the option to pass back the Etag so Azure DNS can verify that the Etag on the server matches. Since each update to a resource results in the Etag being re-generated, an Etag mismatch indicates a concurrent change has occurred. Etags are also used when creating a new resource to ensure that the resource does not already exist.

trans-unit.source:
By default, Azure DNS PowerShell uses Etags to block concurrent changes to zones and record sets. The optional ‘-Overwrite’ switch can be used to suppress Etag checks, in which case any concurrent changes that have occurred will be overwritten.

At the level of the Azure DNS REST API, Etags are specified using HTTP headers. Their behavior is given in the following table:
trans-unit.target:
By default, Azure DNS PowerShell uses Etags to block concurrent changes to zones and record sets. The optional ‘-Overwrite’ switch can be used to suppress Etag checks, in which case any concurrent changes that have occurred will be overwritten.

At the level of the Azure DNS REST API, Etags are specified using HTTP headers. Their behavior is given in the following table:

trans-unit.source: Header
trans-unit.target: Header

trans-unit.source: Behavior
trans-unit.target: Behavior

trans-unit.source: None
trans-unit.target: None

trans-unit.source: PUT always succeeds (no Etag checks)
trans-unit.target: PUT always succeeds (no Etag checks)

trans-unit.source: If-match <etag>
trans-unit.target: If-match <etag>

trans-unit.source: PUT only succeeds if resource exists and Etag matches
trans-unit.target: PUT only succeeds if resource exists and Etag matches

trans-unit.source: If-match *
trans-unit.target: If-match *

trans-unit.source: PUT only succeeds if resources exists
trans-unit.target: PUT only succeeds if resources exists

trans-unit.source: If-none-match
trans-unit.target: If-none-match

trans-unit.source: * PUT only succeeds if resource does not exist
trans-unit.target: * PUT only succeeds if resource does not exist

trans-unit.source: Tags are different from Etags.
trans-unit.target: Tags are different from Etags.

trans-unit.source: Tags are a list of name-value pairs, and are used by Azure Resource Manager to label resources for billing or grouping purposes.
trans-unit.target: Tags are a list of name-value pairs, and are used by Azure Resource Manager to label resources for billing or grouping purposes.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Tags see using tags to organize your Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Tags see using tags to organize your Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS PowerShell supports Tags on both zones and record sets specified using the options ‘-Tag’ parameter.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS PowerShell supports Tags on both zones and record sets specified using the options ‘-Tag’ parameter.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a DNS zone with two tags, ‘project = demo’ and ‘env = test’:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a DNS zone with two tags, ‘project = demo’ and ‘env = test’:

trans-unit.source: A DNS zone is created using the New-AzureDnsZone cmdlet. In the example below we will create a DNS zone called 'contoso.com' in the resource group called 'MyResourceGroup':
trans-unit.target: A DNS zone is created using the New-AzureDnsZone cmdlet. In the example below we will create a DNS zone called 'contoso.com' in the resource group called 'MyResourceGroup':

trans-unit.source: In Azure DNS, zone names should be specified without a terminating ‘.’. For example, as ‘contoso.com’ rather than ‘contoso.com.’.
trans-unit.target: In Azure DNS, zone names should be specified without a terminating ‘.’. For example, as ‘contoso.com’ rather than ‘contoso.com.’.

trans-unit.source: Your DNS zone has now been created in Azure DNS. Creating a DNS zone also creates the following DNS records:
trans-unit.target: Your DNS zone has now been created in Azure DNS. Creating a DNS zone also creates the following DNS records:

trans-unit.source: The ‘Start of Authority’ (SOA) record.
trans-unit.target: The ‘Start of Authority’ (SOA) record.

trans-unit.source: This is present at the root of every DNS zone.
trans-unit.target: This is present at the root of every DNS zone.

trans-unit.source: The authoritative name server (NS) records. These show which name servers are hosting the zone. Azure DNS uses a pool of name servers, and so different name servers may be assigned to different zones in Azure DNS. See delegate a domain to Azure DNS for more information.
trans-unit.target: The authoritative name server (NS) records. These show which name servers are hosting the zone. Azure DNS uses a pool of name servers, and so different name servers may be assigned to different zones in Azure DNS. See delegate a domain to Azure DNS for more information.

trans-unit.source: To view these records, use Get-AzureDnsRecordSet:
trans-unit.target: To view these records, use Get-AzureDnsRecordSet:

trans-unit.source: Record sets at the root (or ‘apex’) of a DNS Zone use "@" as the record set name.
trans-unit.target: Record sets at the root (or ‘apex’) of a DNS Zone use "@" as the record set name.

trans-unit.source: Having created your first DNS zone, you can test it using DNS tools such as nslookup, dig, or the Resolve-DnsName PowerShell cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Having created your first DNS zone, you can test it using DNS tools such as nslookup, dig, or the Resolve-DnsName PowerShell cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t yet delegated your domain to use the new zone in Azure DNS, you will need to direct the DNS query directly to one of the name servers for your zone. The name servers for your zone are given in the NS records, as listed by Get-AzureDnsRecordSet above—be sure the substitute the correct values for your zone into the command below.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t yet delegated your domain to use the new zone in Azure DNS, you will need to direct the DNS query directly to one of the name servers for your zone. The name servers for your zone are given in the NS records, as listed by Get-AzureDnsRecordSet above—be sure the substitute the correct values for your zone into the command below.

trans-unit.source: set type=SOA server ns1-01.azure-dns.com contoso.com
trans-unit.target: set type=SOA server ns1-01.azure-dns.com contoso.com
